hawaiian_text: A lohe 'o 'Ama'u, ho'omākaukau ihola ia i kona mau wa'a kaua he 'umi kumamāwalu, a holo akula i lalo o 'Ewa e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o. A hiki 'o 'Ama'u me kona po'e kānaka ma 'Ewa, e noke mai ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i ka luku ā pau loa, 'a'ohe kanaka koe, a make ihola 'o 'Ama'u. Puni a'ela 'o O'ahu nei iā Nāmakaokapāo'o, a laila, ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine a ho'onoho ihola i luna o ka 'āina O'ahu nei.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: A lohe 'o 'Ama'u, ho'omākaukau ihola ia i kona mau wa'a kaua he 'umi kumamāwalu, a holo akula i lalo o 'Ewa e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o. A hiki 'o 'Ama'u me kona po'e kānaka ma 'Ewa, e noke mai ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i ka luku ā pau loa, 'a'ohe kanaka koe, a make ihola 'o 'Ama'u. Puni a'ela 'o O'ahu nei iā Nāmakaokapāo'o, a laila, ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine a ho'onoho ihola i luna o ka 'āina O'ahu nei.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>A lohe 'o 'Ama'u, ho'omākaukau ihola ia i kona mau wa'a kaua he 'umi kumamāwalu, a holo akula i lalo o 'Ewa e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o. A hiki 'o 'Ama'u me kona po'e kānaka ma 'Ewa, e noke mai ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i ka luku ā pau loa, 'a'ohe kanaka koe, a make ihola 'o 'Ama'u. Puni a'ela 'o O'ahu nei iā Nāmakaokapāo'o, a laila, ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine a ho'onoho ihola i luna o ka 'āina O'ahu nei.</translation>  

<commentary>  
• This passage describes the establishment of O'ahu's name and its connection to a leader named 'Ama'u and his lineage, reflecting themes of territorial naming and ancestral veneration.  
  – The text alludes to the creation of the island’s identity through a figure’s actions, paralleling traditional Hawaiian narratives of land formation and cultural origin.  
  – The phrase "ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine" (carving an image of his wife) suggests ritualistic or symbolic representation of sacred ties to the land.  

• Name symbolism:  
  – **'Ama'u**: "Ama" (to guard/protect) + "u" (suffix), implying "The Guardian" or "The Protector."  
  – **Nāmakaokapāo'o**: "Nā" (the), "Maka" (eyes), "o" (possessive), "ka-pāo'o" (the one who stretches out/extends). "Eyes of the Long Stretch" could symbolize vision or foresight, linking to leadership and navigation.  

  – The name "Nāmakaokapāo'o" may also reference "makahine" (to stretch out) and "pāo'o" (to extend), reflecting the concept of *ʻōlelo pāʻani* (playful language) in Hawaiian lore, where names encode layered meanings.  

• Historical context:  
  – The mention of "luku ā pau loa" (the land of the long night) may allude to the *ʻAi Kapu* era (pre-1819), a period of strict kapu (taboo) systems that governed social and spiritual life. The "long night" could metaphorically represent the rigid, restrictive traditions of that time.  
  – Post-1820 missionary influence introduced changes to Hawaiian governance and spirituality, possibly reflected in the transition from "luku ā pau loa" (long night) to "ki'i akula" (carving an image), symbolizing the shift from sacred to secular practices.  

• Social commentary:  
  – The passage critiques the hierarchical structure of *mo'okūauhau* (genealogical lineage) and *kānaka* (people) in traditional society, where leaders like 'Ama'u were central to territorial identity.  
  – The phrase "e noke mai ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o" (the chief of Nāmakaokapāo'o) may highlight the role of *mō'ī* (rulers) in maintaining *ʻāina* (land) as a sacred entity, a concept challenged by post-contact colonialism.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: When 'Ama'u heard about it, he prepared eighteen of his war canoes and went over to 'Ewa to make war with Nāmakaokapāo'o. When 'Ama'u reached 'Ewa with his men, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work killing them all sparing no one, and that is how 'Ama'u died. All of O'ahu fell to Nāmakaokapāo'o. Then he went and got his mother and set her up as ruler over all of O'ahu.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
